The guests that were with us were all non-korean and seemed to enjoy the food but of course they do not eat Korean BBQ often.  For me, I found myself  acquainting this establishment with the low quality All-you-can-eat places in Los Angeles or Orange County.

The upside is this place is open 24 hours a day, service was fair, and I'm sure they don't always serve spoiled soup.  But once you get my kids sick with your food, I'm done with you.  So...I'm done.

My wife and I have gone there a few times. The last time that we where there I asked for a glass if water. The waitress walked over to the bar and grabbed the 2 used glasses of water that she pulled off a table. That people were drinking out of. then she put a little ice in it and brought it to me. OMG!!!!. my wife and I eat on the strip all most nightly....  I will never go there again
This is the best Korean restaurant in the universe. Unlimited side dishes and soup. Plenty of parking

Come here if you have never seen a server follow you to the front door flapping the guests check holder implying that its empty and I forgot to leave a tip. No, I didnt forget. The service was so poor here I didnt leave one! How ballzy to follow me to the door! 

As a server it is in your job description to do simple tasks such as ask what we would like to drink, take our order and delivery the food to the table. These are minimal service job tasks the customer expects amongst others to make it a pleasurable dining experience. This is what you signed up for and you are getting a wage to do your job. If, however, you want a tip from me why dont you...
1. ask if we would like at least a second cup of hot tea  
2. ask how our meal is
3. ask if there is anything else
4. bring a full glass of cold water instead of a half filled glass, when asked (you couldnt stand and wait a little longer to fill the glass?)
5. say something, anything when you leave the check on the table. 

All these things are also in your job description that I shouldnt have to tip you for.  The only time I saw you was when you took our drink and food order, bring our drink and food to the table and leave our check.  For that, you expect a tip? 

As a local I have been to this restaurant several times for lunch and dinner each time I thought the service was lousy and never warranted me leaving more than a 10% tip. I go back because my elderly Korean mom and I go out for lunch together and she enjoys their buffet of side dishes. My mother was so surprised that a Korean woman, without any self respect and shame would boldly ask for something that she did not deserve. Where are your manners? (My mother is very traditional.)

 That display of flapping the guest check holder would certaintly not fly amongst your Korean tourists.  Were my amerasian features mistaken as some Caucasian tourist that you'll never see again? Yes, I am half Korean.

I am a generous tipper and the amount is based on the service I receive and type of restaurant.  Servers need to stop with the attitude that we are expected to tip. In my book you have to earn it.  

I explained to the server at the front door on the way out why I didnt leave a tip. She never humbled herself and wondered why she didnt get a tip and be concerned if she did something wrong and apologize. She hastily said ok, ok.

There are too many other Korean restaurant's to have to every step foot into this one again! It certainly isn't worth a drive from the NW.

Seems always the last thing we have in our stomachs before with leave the city of sin is the Korean Beef Tang Soup from Kimchi. Located at the end of the strip past encore we've shown up at 7 in the morning after a hard night's work.

It is by no means cheap eats but when you need something comforting and need to skip that burger the soup will satisfy your sinful soul, and help soak up some of that alcohol

They even have a "taxi" (some guy with a minivan) if you need to get home, but i think it only works if you can speak korean.

I've only eaten Korean BBQ twice in my life, and I have never once eaten it at 4 am.  In my drunken state anything would have tasted delicious, and this place sure hit the spot.  I don't really eat the little sides they give us (but that's only because I am super picky) but ate the hell out of meat and rice. Also got to try Korean beer for the first time.   Also hooked us up with some free gyoza but maybe that's because they really seemed to like my Korean friend!

It was going to be quite hard to hail a cab back to our hotel this late at night, so one of the waiters gave us a ride back . Nice!
First Korean BBQ experience. Wasn't sure what to do but server extremely helpful. Prices just right! And super fun and yummy experience.

What was I thinking, going to Vegas and coming out here for dinner. The place was ok, kind of dark from the outside but once inside it's similar to other korean bbq places. The prices were a bit high for Korean bbq, we got tofu soup for $13 and Bulgogi for $27. I thought it better be some good kbbq since we can get AYCE in Koreantown in LA for $16.99. The tofu soup was probably the most bland I have ever tasted. They either did'nt know what they were doing or forgot to add any type of flavor in it. I could cook better at home with a pot of boiling water and some tofu. Huge disappointment. Then comes the meat. It was just ok. Nothing to rave about.

I think what I've learned here is to stick to buffets at Vegas. Even if I hate buffets at least I have more things to hate than 2 bland dishes.

The name is embarrassingly bad.  It's like they had to throw in the word "Kimchi" just to make sure people realize it's a Korean joint.  But the food was eggsszellent.  We hit this place twice in 3 days.

It's a Korean BBQ place, but to be honest, their BBQ is probably the worst thing on their menu.  My recommendations:

1)  Haemul Jongol (spicy seafood stew) - very very good.  But I'd steer away from this if you're not Korean.
2)  Nakchi Bokum (spicy squid dish) - very good.
3)  Undegu Chorim (Monk Fish stew) - Awesome
4)  Sam Gyup Sal BBQ (meat) - this was good actually, the cuts of meat were tender and thicker than normal.  But stay away from the Gal Bi - the meat was good, but man they totally over-marinated it.  The grill got all burned up with all the sugar and sauce from the meat.
5)  Neng Myun (cold noodles) - average, but still good when you're in Vegas heat

The service:
From a Korean perspective, it was pretty bad.  They didn't give you any free dishes no matter how much meat you ordered (bad etiquette), and they rolled their eyes when we asked to change our grill (dude).

But when you get sick of the overpriced Italian food in Vegas, this place really hits the spot.

We were invited to try this place by my girlfriend's family, so I thought it would be a good chance to introduce my family to Korean food. I tend to eat a little more adventurously than my parents and sometimes it can be a challenge to get people to try new things.  

This restaurant is located on the Vegas Strip in a small strip mall. It's very unassuming and as we walked in we were greeted in Korean (well I assume it was a friendly greeting as everyone smiled and we were seated). There are grills at the table and a buffet type bar for the kimchi and other sides that go with your meal.

 We ordered galbi (ribs) and bulgolgi (beef). Both were quite tasty. They were well seasoned and there was plenty of food to go around. They both had their own unique flavors, so I appreciated that as well.  So much so that I ate enough for the rest of the day and it was only 1pm.  

We all enjoyed ourselves and then a cold noodle soup came out that was amazing. It contained noodles, and egg among other ingredients. It has a very nice citrus flavor that was perfect for the warm day. I totally wish I could remember the name of it. Needless to say, I went from stuffed to meal skipping full. 

Tip: This place is open 24/7. Enough said.

It is a little pricy, but when you are eating all you can handle, I would definitely recommend eating here.
Worst Korean BBQ I Have Ever Had By Far I Would Never Recommend This Place To Anyone $29.00 Per Person For a Pick Of 8 Crappy Food For $29.00 GTFO! I Would NEVER Come Here Again
Really good place to load up with very delicious Korean BBQ. The staff is very nice, polite and friendly

Ate here before the food was good, but service horrible. We thought we'd give this place a chance again... We were directed to the opposite side of the room away from any servers and we're were waiting for about 30minutes counting without being noticed. I feel embarrassed and about to leave.  Thank you yelp for allowing a place to share this experience.

After going to quite a few Korean BBQ, I think to get a completable experience, you need to spend way to much money. The good thing is that you can still get a limited menu of 8 items for $22 per person.  

If you really need to get your AYCE Korean BBQ fix, and you are on the strip or at the LVCC, this place works.

Tuesday, lunch time, with my fiancé and his younger brother, mother, and aunt who was visiting from Korea and ALL enjoyed their meals!

Don't be fooled and think you only have to order the all you can eat bbq option because we didn't. We ordered off the lunch menu and with the complimentary banchan, we left stuffed.

First off, the banchan (side dishes) typically served with your meal is serve yourself and ranges from all types of kimchi, potatoes, veggies, and even anchovies- all very typical but very well done.

I got the dduk gook (rice cake soup) and what really impressed me was that I usually have to get the mandoo dduk gook (dumpling and rice cake soup) but I ask for it without the mandoo (dumplings) and they usually try to charge me more! Fear not, they have both options and the soup stock was rich and oh so perfect with the perfectly folded in egg and chewy rice cakes.

Doesn't look like there's much parking from the front but there's plenty in the back! Can't wait to come back after a night of clubbing too :)

Never go there. Everytime they add tips on receipt already. They add 18%, even for 4 ppl. You need to double check.
Sometimes you can pay double tips...
Don't believe their wrong reputation.

Alright now! Ignore these reviews of anyone below 3*, because they were all drunk and expecting $5 meals.  Kimchi is a great korean bbq joint that rivals any that I've been to in the country.  Are the prices high? Well, it's $29 for basically 8 courses of meat, and $46 to add another 6 courses of fish...so, in Vegas prices....NO! We've been a here a few times on our trips, and like to go here to avoid getting molested by Encore/Wynn dining prices.  The food is great. The service is great. They cook for you.  The alcohol (beer, wine, sake) is cheap. Just eat here and ignore the morons who have bashed it.

WOW! where do I start! I was here late night early morning time with a group of 6. no one in the place and after a long wait the waitress finally came over to take our order, we all ordered the same as not to make it to difficult. after another long wait a waitress finally brought us the water that we were eagerly waiting on. I walked over to the buffet table(not too appealing) to see it was half empty with old fruit and what looked like old kimchi and other sides that did not look to appetizing. after again another long wait we start to get our meat cuts and side that come with it. The waitress notices that we have the fire on too high and its creating to much smoke, so she comes over to help and turn down the flames, we then ask if she can change the grill since it has burnt meat on it, she proceeds to change the grill with a noticeable attitude and while doing so spills the meats blood all over the salad and other items that we have been already eating from and all she can says that its ok that we can continue eating and she walks away; we all give each other that awkward stare like did this just happen. so I call her back over and start to tell her that all the food just got contaminated with blood that she spilled while changing the grill, she starts to tell us otherwise we again give that awkward look to each other like is this lady for real are we being pranked. We then asks for our bill and again after another long wait she brings our check and again, after seeing the bill we give that look to each other like this whole meal should be free, but we decide to be good foodies and pay our bill only with no tip, she starts to demand the tip and we all tell her that she should be glad that we are paying for the overly priced meal that we did not eat thanks to her and walked out while she was still demanding a tip. We all walked out of there like never again will we come here even if its the last restaurant standing on the strip, i would rather eat the sand in the desert than be back to this establishment....FOODIES BEWARE!
I come here every time I'm in Vegas. Their kalbi tang is sooo good. They have a banchan bar, which is nice.
Julie was great on the late night. I don't like this kind of food normally but it is good.  It's a fun token too.

My family was craving some korean food and we ended up coming here. The food was alright and then they gave us our bill, they charged us an added gratuity without letting us know. Then when they gave us our receipt, they tried to hide the added tip and asked for more tip. The service wasn't even good.. Don't get fooled by this place. ):

**FOOD POISONING! ENDED UP IN THE ER! REPORTED TO HEALTH DEPARTMENT!**
Please avoid this place. I ate here with my family Saturday night around 9 pm, and by Sunday morning about 1-2 am, I was a disaster. I'm going to skip all of the disgusting symptoms I experienced to save your stomach, but long story short, I ended up in the ER, and today, 3 full days later, am barley returning to normal. CHECK THE BATHROOMS HERE BEFORE YOU EAT! Unfortunately, we visited the bathrooms after, which told me a lot about the condition of the restaurant. Wish I would have looked around before we ate. Buffet sides is what got me sick. Just stay away!

The food is alright, nothing spectacular, just standard Korean BBQ. Definitely had better. My group of five had the all you can eat bbq, and it really was an effort to eat, as the ladies did not help out at all. You grab your own sides, from the little buffet area that they have, and order the meats you want. When you order the meat, they just drop it off for you to cook, and cut. On top of that they add almost a 20% tip for something that was a self serve/ self cook. Not impressed.

first super happy discovery. 

for $17/person all you can eat korean bbq for 1 hour. (not good for ppl who hate to grill/cook their own food - though they will help you with the cooking)

most things are not affordable anymore in vegas. but for a hungry foodie like me, for the price and the quality of the items served, this is 5 stars all the way. 

the pickles, soup, & kim chi are delicious and authentic. 

great value. quite a gem. i am sure i will he back sooner than later. 

highly recommended. 

note: i came off peak hour (1.45 pm). no one here. i bet it would be crazy busy during meal hours/weekend.

I wish I could give no stars! First off they're
Service is HORRIBLE! They basically treat you like crap if don't speak Korean. They're meat is not even  good quality. It's UNHEALTHY- they continue using the same grill at your table with out ever changing it out ! It's like you're eating charcoal. NOT Only THAT THEY ADD THEIR OWN TIP 17% and then when I asked her about it she lied and said it was 15% I'm all for generously giving tips but you  not only lied about the percentage of tip when I calculated the total in front you and it was supposed to be less. What kind of
Business is this place ?! They literally think they can treat customers like crap and then add and over charge them? What a CON! How are they still in business?
Ate there last night. Meat was not fresh. Had stomach ache all night. Don't go there.

Wow the reviews are seriously all over the board on this restaurant, though there aren't that many recent reviews. I actually liked the name of the restaurant. I heard about this place from one of my sales rep's (at Vegas for a convention). Anyways, he was paying for dinner, so I thought I'd try it out.

I just went there tonight on the way to the airport so I was in a rush. We had about forty five minutes, so we had to hurry. We had ordered the dwaen-jang-jigae (soy bean paste soup), bul-go-gi (korean bbq beef) and a stone bimbim-bap (basically a korean version of fried rice but with vegetables and a fried egg on top). The soup was pretty tasty actually not your typical version, they added some go-chu jang (red bean paste) instead.  The bul-go-gi was  your typical run of the mill bul-go-gi (though the next tables kalbi short ribs looked and smelled tantalizingly good).  The bimbimbap was also pretty run of the mill and had I not had the extra bulgogi I would have been pretty disappointed. But it was a perfect addition to the bimbimbap.  The banchan (small korean side dishes that usually come with korean meals) were very tasty. We had about 9 small dishes (bean sprouts, kimchi, radish kimchi, spicy potato, fish cakes, spinach/sesame seed leaves, water kimchi, dried anchovies and one more that I just can't seem to remember).  

Service was actually pretty good and quick even though the restaurant was pretty full. We were out of there with time to spare.

CON:  Price. The price WAS pretty high for what we ordered. It normally would only run about $25-30, but as a fellow small biz owner I understand what they're going through (huge space on the strip). The bill came out to around $55 not including tip. But it's to be expected in Vegas. Isn't everything expensive?

Anyways, I'd go again, I really want to try the galbi next time though.

Wow sure wish me and my GF read all these reviews before we sat down in this Tourists Trap of a place.. We live in OC and go to Garden Grove for great Korean BBQ, this place is Far Far anything that we are accustom too... The service sucked, the food sucked, the bathroom looked like it hasn't been cleaned properly in many years.. In their display case they show old frozen food that is dated over a month old... If your reading this run out of there like its a Zombie Apocalypse!! As I am writing this I can feel my guts flipping like I am about to give birth.. Trust me there are a ton of wonderful spots to eat in Sin City... *****YOU ARE WARNED******

Pricey but worth it. In a city full of AYCE options at every major hotel, I am glad that Kimchi exists. It is probably because of the thousands of Asian tourists that flock to sin city every day.

For $28, you get all the usual Korean meats that you grill on your own. Chadol, bulgogi, galbi...love it! You pick your side dishes from the buffet table. Kimchi executes Asian comfort foods very well.

Service needs improvement. The girl at the front deliberately ignored us for a while before seating us. I have to flag somone down every time we need more meats.

After partying at Surrender, we came here at 3AM for 4th meal. I was so happy when I found out there was a 24hr KBBQ place on the strip. 

In my intoxicated state, we ordered the AYCE. This was a really big 4th meal, and I regretted it the next day. The meat was alright. Nothing special, and I'm sure if I were sober, it wouldn't have tasted the same. 

If I do come here again, it would probably be because I'm hungry and drunk.

My friends and I are from Seattle and we came to get a bite to eat and this was the closest place. Should've checked Yelp before we came here.

The food is below average, the sides are sitting out in the open sitting out to be over cooked or stale. The only good part about the food was the fruit. LOL 

despite the terrible food, I'll say that the staff is at least friendly.

Food was good but nothing special and sides a little below average. 

What really bothers me about this place, was a mandatory 20% tip on a party of three. Now understand this is a principle based issue as the service was fine and I would have tipped that anyway. But it was not stated anywhere ahead of time and that's just not right.

This place looks decent on the inside but the staff was very well not decent and the staff that were bad staff were victory and grace who almost literally dumped meat from the plate and ruined our meal the food was good it's just that they said we couldn't share just so each person would pay and get that extra cent which isn't close to customer satisfaction because my dad wanted to give a piece of meat to my five year old brother and then she said no sharing and it was a very small piece of meat. They brought us many wrong orders and didn't even bring the right meat. I over heard grace saying something to victory in Korean and then grace pointed her finger at us and they charged us extra for switching out the plate which they made the wrong order on. Over all food decent staff very not decent. Please go to the restaurant 2 Miles away that also this kind of barbecue. 
Thank you and I hope you take a moment to look at my review and to never go there.

Came in around 3am after night swim at EBC. Prices are a bit high. The meat was actually pretty good. I felt that the thickness for the meats made it feel like a higher quality. The beef tongue was my favorite! The self serve banchan was pretty nasty. If you're gonna name your restaurant Kimchi - your kimchi better be bomb.

We came in and saw the place was almost empty. It was not a good sign of a tasty restaurant. We ordered bibimbap from the menu and was surprised because it was so bland and no meat to be found. The side dishes were not good either. The kimchi was too sour (it could be old and aged for too long), the fish cake was too chewy. I would not recommend this place.

P/S: they automatically added the tip even though not everyone in the group was eating.

BEWARE! This place adds 15% tip WITHOUT telling you! So for the late night gamblers high on drinks, they are very much likely to add their own 15% tip in the "tip" line!! Unless they were like me, after leaving tip, went back to check the bill and found out the waiter already sneaked in the tip, yet still left the "tip" line empty for you to add and sign!

And i would left double tip had i been serviced well... BUT at this place you had to get up and get your own side dish! Yup, i wouldnt even want to leave 15% if i serviced myself half of the time!

Food was okay, there were two flies flying around in the restaurant.. Burger King is cleaner.

I was very excited to try all you can eat Korean BBQ in Las Vegas for the very first time. I'm originally from Dallas and Dallas has really good BBQ at a reasonable price. I walked in thinking the lunch special (~16 dollars) applied because it was advertised prominently on the store front. Once seated, I asked about the lunch special and the waitress nicely said it was holiday pricing. Still, reasonable price I suppose (~23/person). A plate of lettuce was also an extra 5 dollar charge. The restaurant also had a 1 hr limit... which then my fiancé and I felt pressured to eat very fast. However, half the time the food was not delivered to us in a timely manner and/or the grill was taking forever for our meat to cook. Really, I think we were watching our food cook while drooling more than eating. Side dishes were very mediocre. All the waitresses were nice but they failed to check up on us half the time. Very limited meat selection. Meat quality was just okay and some meat were just too tough. The best meat was the cube shaped sirloin.

Came here for latenight galbi on a recommendation from the dealer... Sides were pretty good, had a different kind of odeng I'm not used to. We also got 2 orders of galbi. One was delicious, the other one was really chewy and hard to eat. They provide both the galbi sauce and the sam gyup sal sauce, both of which were really good.

They added the tip in but that's no problem because they came by and pretty much cooked our BBQ for us. We loved the bulgogi it was pretty much worth the 17 dollars just for that and the unlimited sides are included in the 17 lunch special.

So my Korean wife and I have been going to this place for about 3 years. We visit about twice per month. The bill is most often about $40 to $60 and I always leave more than 20% tip as the waitress is nice. 

Today we ordered the all you. can eat for my 99lb wife and I got a soup. 

The waitress told my wife that the owner notice me taking a few bites and if I did that they would charge me.

I ask to speak with the owner and my points are that my wife only orders 3 meats. A lot less than most. I alway order another dish. Yes i will take a few bites of her leftover meat as they should toss it anyway. My point we order two meals, we visit twice per month and my wife eats half what others eat and to tell his waitress that is dumb and rude. He needs to treat his regulars better.  

Not sure if I will come back after the disrespect
Very helpful staff. I really enjoyed this little spot. Food was very good. This was my first trip to Korean bbq. Highly recommend

You'll find this Korean bbq restaurant on the northern end of the strip. I've been here multiple times and remember the food being above average. I give the place 3 stars because the service is atrocious. 

My friends and I dropped by this place on a Thursday night. The restaurant was nearly empty of patrons. We were seated promptly, but it took forever to get our menus, forever for them to take our order, and forever to get our banchan (side dishes). All those forevers equal an ETERNITY ! The food on the other hand was quite good. Not better than the places in or around LA but still good. 

It is definitely more expensive than LA but it's Vegas so that can be expected. Personally, I'd rather eat here than Ginseng which is just down the strip. 

So if you're in the mood for some Korean, go here. Just don't expect stellar service and big portions.

HaeJangGook for breakfast after the 1st night in Vegas is like winning a jackpot. The panchan buffet is solid. Delish. Hit the spot. Much needed comfort food when in Vegas. Extra bonus, stay at the Encore and it is a 3 minute walk. 30 Korean tourists came in to eat; always a good sign. I didn't have the all you can eat BBQ but the tables were authentic and spacious. TVs on everywhere, Korean and American stations. All employees were Korean. 3 thumbs up. Going there again lunch, probably.

Don't let the cheesy "SPORTS WORLD KIMCHI" sign fool ya, 

This place really serves up some decent Korean fixings off an extensive menu. Though it is a bit pricey considering LA prices. 
 After checkin out the menu, I opted for sulantang-beef soup. The server told me it was "OUT OF ORDER", so I get yu kaejang instead. And it was good. Decent sized portion. At $13.95, it was kinda worth it. I guess less competition raises up the prices. 
 The panchan was ok. Not overly impressive. 
 I do want to come back n try the bbq selections. They all look pretty tasty. And it's a good sized restaurant. 
 If we had more of these 24/7 kinda places in LA, they'd put Denny's out of business!!!
 Definitely worth a visit here for some true Asian fixings, not some of that cheesy stuff they serve in the hotels!

Craving for meat and kbbq flavor when in Vegas!

All you can eat and good deal - $22.  

I like how they have the side self-served ban chan bar so one can pick accordingly!

I like their dipping sauces provided and the salad dressing was great!

Yum!  Superbly full and satisfied!

It's Vegas... and when a group of four tipsy 20-something year olds come stammering into a restaurant at 4 in the morning who are expected to be fed, you know that they are expecting nothing but accommodating food to satisfy them! 

First off, let me mention that there is an all you can eat KBBQ here and while I did not choose this route I will provide some evident opinions from my fellow party-doers. Their beef is pretty fresh and might they recommend the beef tongue (sounds gross but it's so good anywhere, take my word for it). We came in like I said at the crack of dawn so it was not busy at all (we were actually only one of two). What I liked about this place is that the place where you grill all the meat was buttered up so the grill did not get all grungy and charred up, I don't think the waitress had to change the grill at all. Overall, the meat isn't something that is out of this world, but most of my friends said that it was decent.

Secondly, let us move onto my meal. I am a soup connoisseur and so, quite naturally, I bought this noodle soup and I honestly wish I could remember the name but I literally just got done with clubbing and all I know that I was putting into my stomach was a warm bowl of delicious spicy soup! I am sure you can find it if you muster up enough creativity from my review.

The only thing I wanted to mention is that out of the four of us, three had the AYCE and I went the normal entree route and the waitress exclaimed "NO SHARING OKAY?" Which kind of irked me because I am not the type to find loopholes when I eat. So I am going to dock a point off just for that... Harsh? I think not -- my ego is damaged. She proceeds to ask me to help out my friends because they could not finish it all... my have the tables turned?

Overall, you should definitely try Kimchi, it could truly satisfy that insatiable hunger of yours at any time of the day. Just watch out, get AYCE or you can't share!
Really good food they have a hibachi where u cook ur own food  and its all you can eat. Just 30$ and nice staff
Amazing Korean BBQ! Really yummy self serve salad bar. Fresh meat with your usual sticky rice. Very helpful service would love to come back here!

Food is ok. But, again, they charged the tips two times. They gave us the bill with tips included, then when my friend use his credit card made the payment, they asked my friend how much tips he would like to pay. This double tips game was second time I heard , I really feel upset. So, be careful when you receive your bill, pls double check whether they already added the tips in it.

Vegas local here! All you can eat for $22, BUT a few caveats. Great place if you are looking to eat Korean BBQ anytime of the day, the service was rather quick, food was decent, and about $30 per person. We came in around 1AM because we were craving some Asian food and this was the only place nearby that was 24/7. I'm giving this place a 3 Star because they stopped bringing us food even though we were clearly not done eating and they added a 20% tip to the check by default. We were just a party of four, not a big group. Will most likely not be coming back again.

Hidden in a cove away at one end of the strip, this place knows how to BBQ. 

The service was superb, ajummas that are like your auntie who cook the yogi (meat) for you. What was most memorable was the banchan bar (side dishes). It a is self serve station. From the regular korean banchans to california rolls baked sweet potatoes. Definitely provided unique side dishes. After eating at all the vegas strip buffets and even michelin star restaurants, I found that Korean BBQ will always win. Will be returning here next time I visit the sin city.
Very bad. Charged for something we didn't order. Food was very bad. Charged me for extra... very bad do not go here, they over-charged me for things I didn't order.

This is an AYCE Korean BBQ spot on the North end of the "Strip."  Parking is tight, the place is grungy, and the aroma of urine is abundant.  With that said, if you can park and hold your breath, you'll get some decent food.  It is also 24 hours.

Wife and I have been here several times this year.  This time, we had the AYCE lunch for $16.95pp.  We had 3 beef items, 1 pork, and 1 chicken.  There is an AYCE side dish bar full of the normal sides.  I have tasted better kimchee in other places.  All of the food was good, but nothing out of this world.  For us, not very tasty so we added some salt to everything.  Even the marinated dishes was ok (but needed salt.)

They are quick to seat you, and have pretty good service.  Where is falls down is towards the end of the meal.  It says AYCE, and when we devoured all five dishes, no one asks if we wanted more.  In fact, they go out of their way to not come back to your table.  I did want to have more beef, but after waiting for a while just decided not to.  The bill came out to $43 for the both of us.

We would go back, and if you are in the area, we recommend if you are wanting some Korean BBQ.  But don't go out of your way to get here.

WAY OVERPRICED!!!
very unfriendly manager, waitress doesn't speak English...
Food... I lived for 2 years in Korea and can tell you - far below average.
Don't accept AmEx eventhough have a door sticker 'Amex is welcome here".
not recommended, will never go to that place again.

confusing.  I see people walk in and walk out. the don't get it.   well its becuase they advertise on the front as a "buffet" and when you walk in, you dont see the traditional tables full of food. you have to order the meat and the sides are "all you can eat".  it was good and I would go back.

I was surprised to find a decent Korean restaurant in Vegas. 
The name Kimchi World stands for their name because their kimchi was surprisingly delicious. Usually, a lot of Korean restaurants don't have kimchi that taste good however, one of my favorite things about Kimchi World was their kimchi.

I tried their dwaen-jang-jigae (bean paste tofu soup) and kimchi jigae and they were both good.
I also enjoyed the bibin-nang-myun (spicy vermicelli noodle).

I've probably tried this place a handful of times and it never failed me. 
The upside to this place is it is also 24 hours so it a good late night eatery too.

Who knew that there was great Korean food right next door to Wynn Hotel. Checked this place out at 8 AM for A pretty traditional Korean breakfast of soups stews rice and banchan (side dishes).  by the way you grab as much banchan as you want from the buffet style side dish area. You can't go wrong with Galbi Tang!  Go check this place out if you're craving Korean!

For the past few years whenever I visit Vegas I always make it a point to stop here. 

It's not a fancy smanchy place but it's has decent korean food. Service has been okay. I think it has  just varied on who the server was. But to be honest service is not always that great when I go to an asian place. I think it's just a culture difference and not them trying to be rude. But that's not to say they are rude here. They are just a little slow and not to attentive. But when you catch their attention they're cool.

Their pahn chan (side dishes/kimchees) are pretty decent. It's nothing to write home about about but I enjoy it enough to not look for another korean spot.

Tae ji Bul gogi - (bbq pork) It's pretty good, and their chi- gaes (soups) are pretty good too.

I'll be back again. This place is right off the strip near the hotels like Encore, Wynn & Circus Circus.

Ate here after flying in late and looking for something open at that hour. We were the only ones inside. The waitress working was super nice and helpful, I'd say she earned them an extra star on the rating for how good the service was. We got the all you can eat, in retrospect should have just ordered off the menu. The bulgogi was really flavorful. All you can eat was $22/pp. Wish it would have included soft drinks at least, as they only have cans and they're pricey. Overall good food in a not too fancy atmosphere. Only do the all you can eat if you truly have a huge appetite

After reading all the reviews here, I was a bit concerned about the low score. Anyhow, it was so close to our hotel, and we'd decided to give it a try. We went for all you can eat lunch bbq, there were 5 items on the menu, we tried them all. We liked the taste of it and meats were fresh. The best of it is that they have a salad and side dish buffet with a variety of Korean dishes that my husband and I loved so much, we had three plates. We loved their seaweed soup as well that I even asked the owner how it was made. And yes, tips were added to the bill around 20%, I didn't mind cos lots of restaurants in Canada, US and other countries do that. I was gotta tip them well anyways cos the service was great. We were glad that we had a great experience there.

Loved this place! Super friendly staff and yummy food. The kids loved the fresh fruit and veggies to accompany the BBQ. Great selection of meets and delicious dipping sauces. 
They added a tip to the total, so just be aware that they do that. I almost left a double tip!

My friends and I ate at this place during EDC weekend since it was around the corner from our hotel, had AYCE Korean BBQ lunch for $22, and we were hot (104 degrees out) and starving after a night of dancing.

You have two choices: $22 for about 10 meat choices, or $36 for about 16 meat choices. We didn't really know what any of those extra 6 were, so we went with the cheaper option. From those choices, you can order as many as you want, and they bring out plates of raw meat (along with a salad with a vinaigrette that was decent). The servers walk around and help you grill your meat, cutting it up, flipping things, and also putting more on any empty grill space. This bothered us since we were getting full fast, but we learned it's to keep the grill from getting blackened and getting char on the next meat you cook.

The meat all looked fresh and tasted great. There was a ton (and you get charged for excessive leftovers) so we left very full.

My main reasons for not a glowing review were:
Our server was never there when we needed her, most of the time we ended up asking someone else who was passing by for things. And it was not busy, maybe two other tables were there.
The buffet of basic sushi rolls and raw and marinated vegetables was really limited. There was one soup with large chunks of potatoes and carrots that was delicious but the selection was really small compared to other buffets.

One thing we really liked was even though when you order a soda, they bring you a can and a glass of ice, it's included in the AYCE price (as many as you can drink).

This place was something else. Came on our first night in Vegas. My party and I were a bit confused on how it worked or what you had to do. The food ended up being interesting the "salad bar" was a bit weird tho you have no idea what your eating.

Vi bestilte All you Can eat til 27 dollar. Vi fik en bord grill ind og så skulle vi selv tilberede maden, det smagte godt, men ikke 2 besøg værd. Betjeningen var god, men stedet kunne godt trænge til lidt rengøring.

I came here with my wife to satisfy a late night korean bbq craving, but truly fell for their incredible side dishes. The kim chi is delightfully spicy, and complements the massive amounts of meat available at a reasonable price. Service was prompt as well, but the restaurant wasn't too busy at the time. Highly recommended!

I've been going to this place for almost 8 years now with my family every year when we go to Vegas. I am Korean so I know what authenticity tastes like. Everytime we went it was more than satisfying especially the side dish bar which allows for an endless amount of side dishes. However this time it was absolutely horrible. We ordered the yookgaejang and it smelt rotten, the mandoogook used packaged dumplings (which they did not do before) and on top of that it was the wrong dumplings, the soondae was not hot enough leaving my egg yolk raw, the eundaegoo was uncooked and numerous other things. Don't waste your time. I wouldn't nor my money.

Love it! Love it! Did I say love it! Let's see all you can eat for 27.95, we went in there, no special decor or anything but lady was very nice and pleasant, took our orders of: Bulgogi, pork belly, steak and beef tongue (decided to get adventurous here). We went to the buffet to pick our sides, which were plenty! And here we go! Everything was tasty, the 2 sauces they serve were such a great compliment to the thin meats. The tongue was delish! Who would have thought? She brought out some steamed egg that help with all the flavors. We couldn't even finish all that food! Oh but it was great! The only reason I will not give 5 stars is because the rest room was filthy, it look like it hasn't been cleaned in a couple of months. But once I'm out in Vegas I will be back!

I was actually pleasantly impressed by this place given that it has a 3 star rating.

My friends and I were seated immediately by the waiting staff who were quite friendly. The restaurant has a get it yourself condiment bar so the portion sizes were generous. They have fish cake, kimchi, bean sprouts, cucumber, and other various korean side dishes that are quite common. I want to add that the kimchi was quite delicious.

For our entree we ordered the all you can eat korean bbq. So this place has varying levels of all you can eat korean bbq options, but we ended up choosing the cheapest one, which ended up being around $22. I wasn't expecting high quality meat considering how cheap everything was. But, the meat was quite splendid! We ordered the classic bulgogi, chadobaelgi, sam gweop sal, and thinly sliced beef (there was no galbi because that cost more D:). Also, the waiting staff always brought the meat over quickly and was very attentive to whatever our table we needed.

The decor of the restaurant is quite standard. Though I'd say the exterior looks a little tacky and old, the inside was your typical standard korean restaurant. 

Now let me explain why I gave this place 4 stars. The one gripe I had was the automatic gratuity that the place charges. Had I not spotted it I would have been paying a lot more than I should have. Otherwise, solid place; I'd recommend this for anyone in Vegas looking for a bang for your buck kind of meal.

What kind of place sets a time limit on AYCEKBBQ? 1 hour to stuff yourself silly and get your money's worth before time's up. Well, I can discuss more about it since my family and I didn't do the AYCE option since we were a bit fed up with the numerous buffets we've had at the strip.

The menu has your simple, standard Korean fare. The banchan is self-serve, so you can load up as much kimchi as you please. I ordered the hwenengmyun (cold buckweat noodles with slices of skate fish, spicy red sauce drizzled on top, and the usual trimmings for other nengmyuns) and it was delicious. Big portions, but still managed to finish it. Usually, they give you WARM yook-su (beef broth) to "wash it all down", but I was given ICE COLD yook-su, which some crushed ice and all. My Korean mother shook her head for the incompetence.

I'll hand it to them that their food is decent in Korean standards, but it BARELY made the cut.

Open really late maybe even 24 hours i cant remember.  I remember being there at 2am.  Large menu selection.  One of the best dol sat bibimbap i have had, the rice is krispie to signify an actual dol sat!! mmm..and the tofu kimchi dish was rather good, never had it before.  The small dishes are plentiful.  I love the potato one with sweet soy sauce.  I had soon tofu and it was spicy for mild and it tasted pretty good had onions.  Server was ok, probably tired.  Place has a bar with a bunch of tvs around it, place is old and dingy like a nightclub in the daytime.  Btw, its expensive.  $10 soon tofu and $20 kimchi with tofu is a rip off.

Oh man. Bulgogi? Yes, please! Shabu-shabu? Yep, yep!

I love this Korean BBQ. I'd eat there once a week (minimum) if we could afford it. Little spendy.* It's a nice restaurant -- a great place to take a date for a romantic evening, but also comfortable enough that you could just walk in after a big morning at Home Depot in jeans and a T and no one would bat an eye.

The food and service was excellent. I can just feel those beautiful ribbons of beef, sweetly marinated, melting in my mouth. And if you're a vegetarian, fear not -- the side spread they bring out is more than enough to fill your belly if you're dining with carnivorous friends. 

We went with our very good friend from Japan, Mr.Matsui. He proclaims himself a "master chef," and he went bananas while the young lady tried to help prepare our meats. "No, no, no! Thank you!" he stopped her, then sent her away with a demand of, "More garlic! More garlic, please!" It was quite amusing, and luckily, the girl just laughed about it. Wouldn't have been quite so funny if he'd made her feel bad.

I digress. The food's excellent, the service fantastic. I highly recommend this BBQ. It's a little costly (for me), but at Kimchi, you are definitely getting what you pay for.

* "Spendy" must be a West Coast thing. I had never, ever heard it in my life back in the Midwest. I did hear one weird one, though. In Wisconsin, they're fond of using "borrow" inappropriately. Example, "Hey, Linds, will you borrow me that book when you're done?" *shudders*

Avoid this place... I came here with a friend late night and sat down. Looked at the AYCE (all you can eat) menu and it was like $34.99 or was it $35.99 per person! So we left before ordering (as we did, we got bad mouthed from one of the Korean ladies in Korean...) so I can't say for the quality of the food. 

This place was a complete ghost town, and we were the only customers in here by the way! That alone tells me the place isn't all that great.

I moved to Vegas not too long ago from Los Angeles, and this is a complete rip off! A good LA Korean BBQ AYCE charges $14.99 - $19.99 (for premium meats). I understand that this place is open 24/7 and is located right on the strip, right past the "WYNN" on Las Vegas Blvd. 

The prices they charge screams to me "Tourist Trap".
I would never come here or take my friends here. There are so many better ones that are fairly priced in "Spring Mountain" china town area.

I heard this place was really good. Of course, upon arriving here I was prepared to order so many things. But, I was a little discouraged by the prices. This place is pretty expensive. A lot of the dishes are around $20 and up. And the all you can eat deal is $27 and $37 depending on what kind of meats you want. But since I went with a group we just ordered the bibimbap, Mandu soup, and this cold spicy noodle. Overall it was really good. The flavors were on point. But one thing I didn't like was the wait time for the food to arrive. So while we waited we got a bunch of the sides from an unlimited side bar. The sides were reeeeaaallly good.

I regret eating at this restaurant! The food was ok, the service was bad and the price was too expensive! The 15% tip was also enforced on my bill although it was just my self and my husband. This place was a joke!
Excellent everything you can eat bbq. A good place to go when you want to eat meat. We almost try all the meat on the menu

We was party of 4, this is not the first time we eat korean bbq, I tried at least a dozen Korean bbq from east coast to west coast.  Anyway,  I like our waitress,  she was nice,  the side dishes was typical like other korean bbq. The non marinated meats was good, we picked $29.99 buffet with 9 kind of meats, but didn't know there was only 1 , type was marinated,   and the bad thing is the meat wasn't marinated correctly,  it was just sugar,  and not even enough soy sauce,  dash of sesame oil,   it's tasted nothing like korean bbq, so disappointed,  the dipping sauce was so so,  it's not worth it. I won't come back unless if u plan to eat others instead of buffet.

I come from a place where AYCE Korean BBQ is essential in life, and I know damn good Korean BBQ deals when I see one.

Kimchi Korean BBQ is at the end of the strip near circus circus in a plaza that looks like a hooker's front yard. We came here with low expectations on food since.. "pfft, its Vegas who the hell thinks KBBQ out here is gonna be as good as Cali?" These ahjumas (old ladies) can really shove meat everywhere! Damn! The small AYCE list (which I believe is around.. $22 for the "cheap" AYCE but I seriously think that's enough meat for us. You get a PLETHORA of choices. NO JOKE. You pick up your own side dishes at the side dish bar (although I wished there were more options). And any other side dishes you'd have to ask.

Although the cucumber kimchi (Oi sobaegi) wasn't there.. I had asked one lady.. and she said "we're sorry we don't have any." I shit you not. 5 minutes later she comes out with a big plate of it. I guess they either... just made it or they were secretly hiding it from me.

These ladies also REALLY cook your meat. They'll stand there cook, cut, and dispense the meat to you. hell yea.

These ladies are lovely. I'd definitely come back if I were in Vegas again. Hell.. I'll freaking catch gout or something just to eat here!
I would come here for that turnip soup they have at the bar. Other wise, expect typical Korean faires here. Nothing special.

Kimchi Korean BBQ all you can eat is amazing!!!!!

The meat is so fresh, and the setting of the restaurant is clean and comfortable. I don't feel greasy or smell like BBQ when we finish- which is important to me because while in Vegas who wants to smell like meat?!

The all you can eat BBQ is only 22....and it includes everything. The waitress we had was nice enough to do a combination of meats for us instead of just one. Their side dishes, soup, salad and fruits are fresh and delicious too.

Our waitress also helped us cooked the meat and with perfect timing! Soda is kind of expensive (but so is the rest of Vegas), which is $2.50 per can. Overall I'd go again for sure!

24 hour Korean restaurant next to Encore. I think I've been here about 10 times and after all that I'd say the all you can eat is the best deal. Everything else on the menu is average at best. The bbq entrees aren't good enough to order alacarte. Service is pretty inconsistent.  Understaffed as we were rarely checked on. Side dishes are self serve buffet style which is kinda annoying but at least we can pick what we want.

It's an actual Korean restaurant on the strip.  Pricing is good.  However, its a bit lazy.  For example, banchan is served via an all you can eat bar.   That's all well and fine, but it doesn't really give a Korean experience.  I ordered the Soon Tofu which didn't come bubbling as I would have liked.  Service was okay.

If you want  authentic Korean food, don't go there.
The side dishes and entree was either bland or too sweet. I guess being on the strip they must have decided to make the food sweet to appeal to non-Koreans (especially Japanese). That was the only logical conclusion I can think of because Korean food should not be sweet.
The kimchee hot stone pot rice came out warm with kimchee juice still on the bottom. So, I told them to take it back. It came back 10 min. Later. Still not right and warm-it should be sizzling. My soy bean (den Jang chee gae) was too sweet as well as bland. So, I called the manager but the waitress never called one for me. So, I complained to her that it was one of the worst Korean food I've had in a long time.  I am visiting from los angeles, which has one of the best Korean restaurants outside of Korea. So, I think I know what I am talking about.
It's so sad because I was here for super bowl Sunday. It was not bad. They must have change the cooking concept since to attract the non-Koreans. If I was alone, I would have cancelled the order and walked out.

Trust me, stay away unless you like your food bland and sweet.

There are better Korean restaurant. I think Ginsang on the south side on the strip is better. The Korean restaurant on the strip pass the Stratosphere is better. The Korean restaurant in the old shopping center on Sahara, north of the strip is better.

The last two times i have been to Vegas i have come here for their AYCE KBBQ. I came across this place because my friends and i had just left XS en route to the peppermill for breakfast foods and in the corner of my eye i saw the bright sign that said 24hr AYCE BBQ. Needless to say.... we flipped a U and pulled into the parking lot for some grub.

I am probably not the best judge for this place because both times i visited i was under the influences of alcoholic beverages. However i can say with confidence that the meal was alright. For 4am AYCE KBBQ it definately hit the spot. 

On both visits i pretty much order the same typical meat selection. I have to say that i did like the dressing on the salad that they served us however the steam eggs were hit or miss. The first time i went the eggs were perfect and fluffy and the second time they were overcooked to say the least. 

This is not the best KBBQ i have ever had and to be honest it doesnt come close to the best, but so midnight post party eating i say its pretty good. 

The 2 things that turned me off are as follows:

A friend and i had asked to split the tab with two credit cards and the host split the charges but used my card twice. So basically my card was changed the entire meal. Not a big deal because my friend just gave me cash but it was kind of annoying.

 We asked the host to call us a cab which turned out to be like a friend/family member/owner of the place. The driver tried to overcharge us for the ride back to our hotel and when we objected he gave us a more reasonable price. Who did he think we were?? Vegas Newbs??? Sorry mister... its does not cost more than $20 bucks to drive a few blocks in Vegas.

I remember going to Kimuch and I liked their food years ago.  So I brought bunch of my "Fashion Friends" during MAGIC (Las Vegas Fashion tradeshow).

When I first entered the restaurant, I had good feeling about the place since 90% of the customers were Korean and Japanese.

I ordered bunch of BBQ item- Bulgogi (marinaded sliced beef), Ross Gui (sliced beef without marinade), and Hya Mit Gui (sliced beef tongue) for the table.
All the meat tasted tender and fresh.  I really liked Hya Mit Qui.  It was very tender and flavorful.  The sesame oil accompanied the dish was very good quality.
All the BBQ dishes came with Man Doo (meat dumplings) and Naengmyeon (cold noodles).  I didn't like neither of these dishes.  The noodles tasted soggy without texture and Man Doo was not flavorful.   

My vegetarian friend ordered Jab Chae (fried clear been thread noodle with vegetables) and Bibimba (vegetables and a fried egg on the rice) without meat.  She really enjoyed both of the dishes.

I was happy to see they had OB beer which goes very well with Korean BBQ.

They also have a private room to seat 15-25 people.  I don't think Kimuchi has the best Korean food nor decor but I defanatly had a great time after having networking / business dinners at "shi shi" Koi / Tao kind of the restaurants every night.

I discovered this place almost 10 years ago by accident and it's on my "to do" list every time I'm in Vegas.
I'm not a Korean BBQ aficionado by any means, so I can't speak to the authenticity of the food. But everyone I've taken there over the years, sometimes unwillingly or scared, has left completely satisfied and surprised at how much they liked it.
Everything is super tasty and the staff is great at guiding you through what dishes people typically order. 
A good beginners menu, for two people, would be one meat order (bulgogi). And one soup order (tofu, with seafood and beef). Add more as you go if needed.
There's also an "all you can eat" option. But I've never done that.
They'll even help cook your food on your grill if you're completely lost.
There's also a large "sides" bar, which I believe is complimentary. So many great choices that you might start to get full before your meat is cooked. The spicy cucumber slices are my favorite.
And of course, the Kimchi. Delicious. Smooth and crunchy with just the right amount of sour.
I might also add that it's located in a small shopping center. So it's very easy to get in and out of, and park.

The place is like any other korean restaurants i have been to in southern california area. Their meat were good as well as the side dishes. I liked the glass noodles, but it didn't come with the buffet so you have to order it separately. Only few customers where eating on a weekend, probably because of its location.

My favorite place in Las Vegas for Korean food , the unlimited side dishes are great The noodle dish:Naengmyeon is my favorite, very friendly service and they can make this and other dishes without meat if you are a vegetarian like me;)

I've been here 4 times or so over the years, and food and service has been good.  But went there 1/1, and it took 45 minutes for our order to come out.  I always get the Yuk Kae Jung, which has been very consistent.  This time my friend got the Kimchi Chi Gae and Dwae Je Pu Gogi- which we couldn't figure out what it was suppose to be.

24 hr AYCE, came in at around 11:30 pm or so on a Thursday night. Nothing super special about this place. It wasn't super special, but there's not a bad thing I could really say about this place either. Meats were good, the bulgogi marinade was actually sweeter than what I'm used to. Not a bad taste, but good. Just didn't wow me that's all. What's cool though is they have a buffet of their sides so you can help yourself to more sides as you wish, and not have to bug the waitress to get more for you everytime. Customer service was fine, the waitress was attentive to us. I've never been here before, I may come back again. But I like trying out different KBBQ places.

24 hour Korean bbq.  What could be better than that?  

oh... I dunno...one that actually cooks good food?  Maybe it was because they just didnt' care at midnight...but this whole idea of pseudo buffet was not really that good.  Hubby had kalbi...and for the price it was, well... you should of seen his face... The soondubu kind of wannabe was not very tasty... and honestly only the bibimbap was ok.  This is not saying much as we were ALL FAMISHED by this time. For the food to be less than ok at this time of night when we were really hungry says alot.  

Lack of attention to service, just overall odd. 
I hate to say it wasn't good, but this is just not worth it. 
Maybe they had an off night, but I wouldn't go back.  
Not when I've had better Korean food in Vegas.  And not when there are so many other awesome places to eat at... for better prices and taste!

My experience at kimchi was ok, the meats are fresh and tasty but the side dishes are not good, not many choices and you grab them yourself, our grill was super burned they did not change it(gross) no ice cream for dessert was a bummer... $22 all u can eat hmmm not worth the money beware they add 15% tip on your bill lol smh I'm not going back.
It wasn't busy at all but I did not get my tea before the meal. Good thing you can grabbed yummy banchans aka side dishes as much as you want lol

This is an all you can eat Korean BBQ restaurant located right on the strip. The buffet is $22, but you can also order a dish from their menu. (Most dishes are $13-15 which is reasonable since it's on prime realty). My family and I came in here after hearing about it in the newspaper. After eating several buffets, I think we were all looking for something a bit more.. tame. 

I ordered the soon tofu, which was good. The family ordered cold noodles and den jang stew, which they seemed to enjoy. But the silver lining was the all you can eat side dishes. YUM. My favorite side dishes were: the seaweed, potatoes, and acorn jelly. They might sound strange, but they were tasty. They also had a sushi bar too, but I was too full to even try to tackle that beast.

The next time we're here in Vegas we don't have to worry about driving around finding a Korean restaurant.
Their food sucks! The worst korean bbq i ever tasted. If there was an option for no star, i would choose that. Very disappointing and service is bad. I shouldve ate at mcdonalds instead.
This place was great! Delicious and great service! The only reason it did get 5 stars was because of the bathroom was disgusting. Otherwise GREAT food! Good price for what you get!
It's not the best service, not the best price, and not all the best Korean food you could want to eat.... They do have THE BEST ribeye on their all you can eat menu.

DO NOT EAT HERE! The food taste bad and not fresh plus they add 20% TIP no matter how many people eat.
Worst place to eat Korean food in Vegas!

Super expensive. When the conventions come to town, they remove their weekday special. Though their salads, and side dishes are bountiful; the meats are slim. The service is slow. Plus they add their own tips at 20%. The is an hour eating limit. Any other menu items start at $16. Even the grilled fish or tofu soup. Remember its a buffet. But their "washed" plates are dirty, greasy & crusty.

I had the bulgogi & ojingeo bokkeum so I cant speak for the rest of the food but those 2 foods werent half bad. This place is really underrated as their food in my opinion, reflects 4 stars.

Food - flavorful, not just all spicy, my favorite part is the salad bar of all you can eat banchan as well as all you can eat dessert ANY order. Even if you order just one thing.

Price - its very pricey here but its vegas, what do you expect. The bulgogi was $29 and the ojingeo bokkeum was $25. If you were to go here, i recommend getting the all you can eat kbbq which is $29 per person. Its more worth since a dish of bbq is $29-$42

Only complaint - price is not worth portion size but its Vegas what do you expect

This is place is way over priced. Bulgogi BBQ beef  $27 ? Side dishes tasted old  & terrible . I would not recommend this place at all.  I couldn't even finish my meal & threw my left over away. Try at your own risk ~
Shittiest korean restaurant ive been to in my life. Way overpriced. Small ass portions. Bathroom smells like puke. Side dishes smell old. Workers don't do anything.

Had their Kalbi Tang.  Good quality, not very greasy like I've had at other restaurants.  Good Banchan.

Looked to be a bit pricey on their BBQ menu, but good quality and close to TI.

Food is average, but service is much worse compare to the average.

1. They refused to change grill pad after it's burned. 

2. They don't bring you all the food you ordered at once, only give you the next dish after last one is finished.

3. They automatically added a 18% tip to your bill without let you know. We almost double tipped, and I'm sure that's been happening very often.

Do not use their website to do online ordering!!!!!

I remembered that I ate here in 2012 and the all you can eat Korean BBQ was delicious and the place was packed at that time, even on weekdays. So, when I visited Vegas with my boyfriend's family and they wanted something soupy for to-go dinner, I remembered about this place's Korean soups. 

To save time, I was planning to go to their website to see the menu and call them first. Well, I found in their website that there was a menu for online ordering. I thought 'nice, so perfect and convenient'. I put in all my orders and my information and I thought that my food will be ready once I got there. 

Well well well, guess what? The Korean ahjumma (lady) who greeted us didn't know about our orders, she didn't even know that the restaurant had an online ordering system!! She asked the other ahjummas and they were all clueless. I was like whattt???? I was already tired from my drive from LA, so I didn't have energy to get mad. I checked my credit card account and thankfully it wasn't charged. So, I had to order again and wait 15 minutes for them to make my food.

I came on a Saturday night and the place was deserted, even though Tacos el Gordo (in the same plaza) was like crazy packed.

Thankfully, the food that I ordered came out really delicious (or maybe we were too hungry). But, I was already turned off by the online ordering incident.
Very good Korean food. If you like meat then order the all you can eat plater

I did not like this place. It is not sanitary and kinda on the downscale side. The worst part was that they charged 15% gratuity for a party of 4. The all you can eat korean bbq for $22 did not give you lots of selection choices of meat. I would definitely not recommend this place or ever go back. There's too many better restaurants in vegas for less less.

This place is hella expensive! But then again, it's still all you can eat amazing-ness. They have a huge range of different meats and also have a really clean and nice looking place. 

The downside to this place is that the service was horrendous (although very nice people). They would put the meat on the table grill themselves and then leave, leaving me unsure as to whether I'm supposed to continue the cooking myself or wait for her to come back. So I did it myself and then she came back and finished it. 

Regardless of that con, it's a great place to eat out at night, especially since it's open 24 hours!

This place would have gotten a better review but since they try to rip off tourist I will not recommend it how can the place charge gratuity for 7+ ppl when it's only 2 people eating CHECK YOUR BILL b4 paying besides that good is good

i ONLY come here when i visit las vegas with my parents. if i don't come with my parents i refuse to eat here....

why?

BECAUSE THIS PLACE IS A RIP OFF!!!

this place sells average korean food for a crap load of money! 
for instance, soon doo boo in la is 8.99? here its a whopping 13.99!!! HUH!!???
also, normally all you can eat bbq is around 23 with tax? but here? its 30 dollars! HUHHHHH?????????!!!!

it just doesnt make sense to me......

Authentic Korean food. They speak Korean. They serve you real sesame oil with your bbq and they have amazing duk guk soup, which is rice cake soup. I wish we would have known about this place sooner and it was closer to our hotel than Biwon (you can read that review over there) was. Not sure why this place has low ratings. Obviously Vegas ppl don't know what real Korean food tastes like. Poor souls. Anyway great place. Their menu is in Korean, English, Japanese and Chinese. They also have ayce banchan and they know you have to heat the grill up first before adding it right away, unlike Biwon.

It's not what I remembered it to be, $45/person? And we were still hungry at the end? And we didn't even get much alcohol? We paid 50 bucks for kalbi? That wasn't even all that great to begin with? WOW! 

Still the restaurant of choice when my and the girlfriend comes.

The worst experience in a Korean restaurant, after they ignored me for 5 minutes finally got a table. I check the menu and I ordered the all you can eat but surprise, the lady told me. We don't have time for that you have to order something else

Came here while in Vegas and it was a pretty good restaurant. The side dishes are good and so are the dishes in general. The service was good and the waitresses were really cute ajummas lol Nice and clean! A good place to come if you are craving some old fashioned korean bbq!
